case_name: Civil Appeal No. 846 of 1972 and Civil Appeal No. 1343 of 1973

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 846 of 1972 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 22, 1971 of the Delhi High Court in S.A.O. No. 83-D of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 846 and 1343 of 1972. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 22, 1971 of the Delhi High Court in S.A.0. No. 83-D of 1965

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1343 of 1972 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 22, 1971 of the Delhi High Court in S.A.O. No. 239-D of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: And Civil Appeal No. 1343 of 1973 Appeal by Special leave from the judgment and order dated November 22, 1971 of the Delhi High Court in SAO No. 239-D of 1965. M. Tarkunde, S. S. Shukla and A. P. Gupta, for the appellant

facts.text: The Delhi High Court allowed the appeals filed by the two respondents (landlords).

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals by special leave are against the judgment of the High Court of Delhi allowing the ,appeals filed by the two respondents. The respondents are landlords of two houses in the Karol Bagh area of Delhi.

facts.text: Respondents are landlords of two houses in the Karol Bagh area of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are landlords of two houses in the Karol Bagh area of Delhi. The houses are built on lands given on long lease by the Delhi Improvement Trust to the rights, liabilities and assets ,of which the Delhi Development Authority has since succeeded.

facts.text: Houses built on lands given on long lease by the Delhi Improvement Trust, succeeded by Delhi Development Authority.

anchor.surface_text: The houses are built on lands given on long lease by the Delhi Improvement Trust to the rights, liabilities and assets ,of which the Delhi Development Authority has since succeeded. Under the terms of the lease, subject to revision of rent, the lessees were to put up residential buildings on the leased lands.

facts.text: Lease terms require residential use only; void if used otherwise without lessor's written consent.

anchor.surface_text: Under the terms of the lease, subject to revision of rent, the lessees were to put up residential buildings on the leased lands. ,and the lessees undertook number to use the said land and buildings that may be erected thereon during the Said term for any other purpose than for the purpose of residential house without the companysent in writing of the said lessor provided that the lease shall become void if the land is used for any purpose than that for which the lease is granted

facts.text: Present landlords are successors in interest of original lessees.

anchor.surface_text: number being a purpose subsequently approved by the lessor. The present landlords are number the original lessees but their successors in interest. Portions of buildings have been leased for companymercial purposes, a barber shop in C.A. 846 and a scooter repair shop in C.A. 1343.

facts.text: Portion of building in C.A. 846 leased to tenant for barber shop (commercial use).

anchor.surface_text: The present landlords are number the original lessees but their successors in interest. Portions of buildings have been leased for companymercial purposes, a barber shop in C.A. 846 and a scooter repair shop in C.A. 1343. The Delhi Development Authority appears to have given numberice to them drawing their attention to the provision of the lease extracted above

facts.text: Portion of building in C.A. 1343 leased to tenant for scooter repair shop (commercial use).

anchor.surface_text: Portions of buildings have been leased for companymercial purposes, a barber shop in C.A. 846 and a scooter repair shop in C.A. 1343. The Delhi Development Authority appears to have given numberice to them drawing their attention to the provision of the lease extracted above and that as they had permitted the buildings to he used for companymercial purposes

facts.text: Delhi Development Authority gave notice to landlords for permitting commercial use contrary to lease terms, threatening lease determination.

anchor.surface_text: The Delhi Development Authority appears to have given numberice to them drawing their attention to the provision of the lease extracted above and that as they had permitted the buildings to he used for companymercial purposes companytrary to the terms of the lease deed, the lease was liable to be determined and called upon them to discontinue the use of the land for companymercial purposes, failing which they were asked to show cause why their lease should number be determined and the land, together with the buildings thereon, reentered upon without any companypensation to them.

facts.text: Landlords issued notice to tenants to stop commercial use and instituted eviction proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the landlords issued numberice to the tenants asking them to stop the company- mercial use of the buildings and later instituted the proceedings out of which these appeals arise. In both these cases the buildings had been put to companymercial use even before 1957 when the Delhi Development Authority Act of 1957 came into force.

facts.text: Buildings put to commercial use before 1957 when Delhi Development Authority Act 1957 came into force.

anchor.surface_text: In both these cases the buildings had been put to companymercial use even before 1957 when the Delhi Development Authority Act of 1957 came into force. The Controller dismissed the petitions filed by the landlords and the appeals filed by them were dismissed.

facts.text: Controller dismissed petitions filed by landlords.

anchor.surface_text: The Controller dismissed the petitions filed by the landlords and the appeals filed by them were dismissed. They thereupon filed appeals to the High Court. A learned single Judge of the High Court taking a view companytrary to two earlier decisions

facts.text: Appeals filed by landlords to High Court after dismissal by Controller and appellate authority.

anchor.surface_text: The Controller dismissed the petitions filed by the landlords and the appeals filed by them were dismissed. They thereupon filed appeals to the High Court. A learned single Judge of the High Court taking a view companytrary to two earlier decisions in Smt. Uma Kumari v. Jaswant Rai Chopra 1  and S. P. Arora v. Ajit Singh  2   referred the question that arise in these appeals to a Division Bench

facts.text: Delhi High Court Division Bench decided in favour of landlords, contrary to earlier single judge decisions.

anchor.surface_text: A learned single Judge of the High Court taking a view companytrary to two earlier decisions in Smt. Uma Kumari v. Jaswant Rai Chopra 1  and S. P. Arora v. Ajit Singh  2   referred the question that arise in these appeals to a Division Bench which took a view companytrary to that taken in the two earlier decisions above referred to, and decided in favour of the landlords.

facts.text: Leases granted in 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The provision of clause  k  of the proviso to sub- section  1  of section 14 is something which has to be given effect to whatever the original companytract between the landlord and the tenant. The leases were granted in 1940, and the buildings might have been put up even before the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act 1952 came into force.

facts.text: No dispute that parts of buildings used contrary to residential condition in lease.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the lease granted by the Delhi Improvement Trust, the predecessors in interest of the Delhi Development Authority, to the predecessors in interest of the landlords companytains a companydition that any building to be erected on the land shall number be used for any purpose other than residential purpose. There is numberdispute that part of each of the buildings is being used in a manner companytrary to that companydition.

facts.text: Landlords gave notice to tenants to cease commercial use.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that part of each of the buildings is being used in a manner companytrary to that companydition. The landlord has also given numberice asking the tenant to cease using the building for that purpose.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds landlords not estopped from evicting tenants despite letting for commercial use.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberestoppel here because both the landlord and the tenant know that the tenancy was number one permitted under the terms of the lease of the land. In any- case there can be numberestoppel against the statute.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeals, sets aside High Court judgment, remands to Controller for decision under Section 14(11).

anchor.surface_text: The appeals are allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside. The matter will have to go back to the Controller for A.I.R. 1959 S.C. 689. deciding the question under sub-section   1 1   of section 14 whether he should exercise the one or the other of the two alternatives mentioned therein. As already mentioned, numberorder awarding companypensation under the second alternative given in that sub-section can be made except in the presence of the Delhi Development Authority.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 22, 1971 of the Delhi High Court in S.A.0. No. 83-D of 1965 And Civil Appeal No. 1343 of 1973 Appeal by Special leave from the judgment

Section 14 of the Delhi Rent Control Act 1958, which deals with the question of protection to tenants against eviction, in so far as it is relevant, is as follows 14.  1  Notwithstanding anything to the company- trary companytained in any other law or companytract, numberorder or decree for the recovery of possession of any premises shall be made by any companyrt or Controller in favour of the landlord against a tenant Provided that the Controller may, on an application made to him in the prescribed manner, make an order for the recovery of possession of the premises on one or more of the following grounds only, namely-

concepts.interpretation: Applies where tenant uses premises contrary to letting purpose without consent; distinguished from clause (k) as for different situations.

concepts.interpretation: Allows eviction where tenant uses premises contrary to conditions imposed on landlord's lease by authorities like DDA, even if landlord consented to such use; intended to enforce authority lease conditions and prevent unauthorized use; applies despite landlord's contract with tenant.

I.L.R.  1970  11 Delhi 130. .lm15 behalf by the Controller, companyplies with the companydition imposed on the landlord by any of the authorities referred to in that clause or pays to that authority such amount by way of companypensation as the Controller may direct.

concepts.interpretation: Provides alternative to eviction: tenant can comply with condition or pay compensation directed by Controller to authority; Controller to decide between eviction or compensation; requires presence of authority for compensation order.

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of the Delhi Development Act 1957 is as follows After the companying into operation of any of the plans in a zone numberperson shall use or permit to be used any land or building in that zone otherwise than in companyformity with such plan Provided that it shall be lawful to companytinue to use upon such terms and companydition as may be prescribed by regulations made in this behalf any land or building for the purpose and to, the extent for and to which it is being used upon the date on which such plan companyes into force.

concepts.interpretation: Does not apply to enforce lease conditions; allows continuance of prior uses subject to regulations (none framed); no relevance to eviction under Rent Act.

issues.text: Are the landlords estopped or otherwise prohibited from getting possession of the property from the tenants because they themselves had let it out for companymercial purposes.

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for decision in these cases is this Are the landlords estopped or otherwise prohibited from getting possession of the property from the tenants because they themselves had let it out for companymercial purposes.

issues.text: Does clause (k) of the proviso to sub-section (1) of section 14 apply only where the tenant has used the premises after previous notice from the landlord at the beginning of the tenancy notwithstanding the landlord's consent to commercial use?

anchor.surface_text: It has been argued on behalf of the tenants that this clause will apply only where the tenant has used the land after previous notice from the landlord, i.e., if the landlord had told him at the beginning of the tenancy that the building was number to be, used for companymercial purposes and notwithstanding that the tenant used it for a companymercial purpose. They, therefore, contend

He need number depend upon clause k at all. These two clausesare intended to meet different situations. There was numberneed for anadditional provision in clause k

The only situation in which it can take effect is where the lease is for a companymercial purpose agreed upon by both the landlord and the tenant but that is companytrary to the terms of the lease of the land

The policy of the legislature seems to be to put an end to unauthorised use

arguments.claim: Section 14 Delhi Development Act applies requiring eviction for non-conforming use

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has arrived at its companyclusion on the basis that section 14 of the Delhi Development Act applies to this Case. We shall presently show that that section has numberrelevance to the decision of this case. It is under the terms of the lease granted by the Delhi Improvement Trust

arguments.court_reasoning: S14 DDA regulates post-plan uses, allows prior uses till regulations (none framed); case turns on lease terms, not DDA

arguments.claim: Clause (k) overrides original landlord-tenant contract; gives effect regardless of consent

anchor.surface_text: The provision of clause k of the proviso to sub- section 1 of section 14 is something which has to be given effect to whatever the original companytract between the landlord and the tenant. The leases were granted in 1940, and the buildings might have been put up even before the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act 1952

arguments.claim: S14 DDA has no relevance; prohibition via lease terms, prior use continuable absent regulations

anchor.surface_text: It is under the terms of the lease granted by the Delhi Improvement Trust that the use of this building for companymercial purpose is prohibited and-not under the Delhi Development Act. Furthermore, section 14 applies number only to lands leased by authorities like the Delhi Development Authority companytaining companyditions against unauthorised user

holdings.text: Landlords are not estopped or prohibited from obtaining possession from tenants under clause (k) of Section 14(1) despite having let the premises for commercial purposes, as both parties knew the tenancy violated the superior lease terms and there can be no estoppel against a statute.

anchor.surface_text: There is no estoppel here because both the landlord and the tenant know that the tenancy was not one permitted under the terms of the lease of the land. In any- case there can be no estoppel against the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both parties aware of superior lease violation precludes estoppel; doctrine of no estoppel against statute applies; clause (k) overrides private arrangements.

holdings.text: Clause (k) of the proviso to Section 14(1) applies where tenant uses premises contrary to conditions in the landlord's superior lease from authorities like DDA, notwithstanding landlord's consent or lack of prior notice at tenancy inception.

anchor.surface_text: It has been argued on behalf of the tenants that this clause will apply only where the tenant has used the land after previous notice from the landlord, i.e., if the landlord had told him at the beginning of the tenancy that the building was not to be, used for commercial purposes and notwithstanding that the tenant used it for a commercial purpose. They, therefore, contend

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rephrases estoppel argument rejected earlier; clause (k) distinct from clause (c); purposive interpretation to give effect to provision.

holdings.text: Clauses (c) and (k) of the proviso to Section 14(1) address different situations: clause (c) for misuse contrary to tenancy terms without landlord consent; clause (k) for misuse contrary to superior lease conditions even with landlord consent.

anchor.surface_text: If it is a case where the tenant has contrary to the terms of his tenancy used the building for a commercial purpose the landlord could take action under clause c . He need not depend upon clause k at all. These two clauses are intended to meet different situations. There was no need for an additional provision in clause k

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction avoids redundancy; clause (k) operative only where landlord consents but violates authority lease.

holdings.text: Clause (k) of Section 14(1) must be given effect notwithstanding the original contract between landlord and tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The provision of clause k of the proviso to sub- section 1 of section 14 is something which has to be given effect to whatever the original contract between the landlord and the tenant. The leases were granted in 1940, and the buildings might have been put up even before the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act 1952

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory override explicit in 'notwithstanding' clause; historical context from predecessor Act confirms.

holdings.text: The tenancy was not void ab initio merely because it was for unauthorised use under the superior lease.

anchor.surface_text: We thus reach the conclusion that the lease in its inception was not void nor is the landlord estopped from claiming possession because he himself was a party to the breach of the conditions under which the land was leased to him. Neither the clear words of the section,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear words of section and policy do not support voidness; cites precedent Waman Shriniwas Kini.

holdings.text: Controller has discretion under Section 14(11) to order either eviction or tenant compliance with superior lease condition or payment of compensation to authority; High Court erred in mandating eviction only.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Avoids rendering s14(11) useless; authority presence required for compensation order; discretion to apportion responsibility.

holdings.text: Section 14 of the Delhi Development Act 1957 has no relevance to eviction under clause (k) of the Delhi Rent Control Act, as prohibition arises from lease terms, not zoning plans, and prior uses continuable absent regulations.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes lease enforcement from zoning; no regulations framed allowing prior commercial uses to continue.

holdings.text: No order for compensation under the second alternative of Section 14(11) can be made except in the presence of the Delhi Development Authority.

anchor.surface_text: As already mentioned, no order awarding compensation under the second alternative given in that sub-section can be made except in the presence of the Delhi Development Authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit from statutory text requiring payment to authority.

holdings.text: The appeals are allowed, the High Court judgment set aside, and the matter remanded to the Controller to decide under Section 14(11) whether to order eviction or the alternative remedy.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural outcome based on reversal of High Court errors on clause (k) applicability and discretion under 14(11).
